metadata.sermon_start_end: Did you see the front page of the Friday New York Times? Here it is. Right here along with Clinton’s visit to China we see this headline: “Vatican Settles a Historic Issue With Lutherans.” [...] According to the limitless grace of God, may it be the same for us. AMEN.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon fails Dekker’s requirement for a 'specific' passage. It treats the entire Epistle to the Galatians as a thematic source rather than a single pericope. It functions as a speech about the 'idea' of justification rather than an exposition of a unique text. It does not identify what can be found in a specific verse that exists nowhere else.
quotes: Text: The Epistle to the Galatians
If you wanted to find the most concentrated teaching on justification in the Bible, where would you look? You would look in the Epistle to the Galatians
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Select one specific pericope (e.g., Galatians 2:15-21) and focus exclusively on the linguistic and theological particularity of those verses instead of surveying the whole letter.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: There is a clear attempt to understand the original context as a 'field of battle' and the role of the 'false teachers.' The preacher uses a specific scholarly translation (J. Louis Martyn), which indicates engagement with exegesis, though the technical depth is sacrificed for narrative flow.
quotes: Paul understands himself to have been directly commissioned by Jesus to be the commander of the gospel forces.
He leaves out most of the customary greetings that people of his time used at the beginning of letters
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Deepen the exposition by explaining the specific nature of the 'Law' in the Galatian context (e.g., circumcision/boundary markers) rather than equating it immediately with general 'religion'.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is the strongest element. The preacher connects the text to the zeitgeist (NY Times, Clinton, AA, racism, procrastination). It avoids 'general truths' by addressing the specific psychology of the modern hearer's 'bound will.'
quotes: The 'just say no' campaign against drug use has been widely ridiculed because people came to see that it’s not so simple.
Procrastination is one of my besetting sins... That well-intentioned soul has not yet grasped the idea of the bound will.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Ensure the application remains tied to the specific text's logic rather than drifting into a general psychological lecture on the 'bound will'.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: Exposition and application are reasonably mixed. The preacher moves from Paul’s 'battle' to the hearer’s 'battle' with self-will. However, the first half is heavily introductory/historical, and the second half is heavily applied, creating a slight structural split.
quotes: Paul uses opposites constantly... Let me try to illustrate this. A lot of us are really trying not to be prejudiced or racist.
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Avoid the long introductory section about the New York Times and start directly within the text, drawing the hearer into the Greek 'rectification' immediately.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The sermon strongly emphasizes 'misery' (the bound will, the inability to save oneself) and 'redemption' (God's act in Christ). 'Gratitude' is present but less developed, appearing mostly in the concluding remarks on the Holy Spirit.
quotes: Whatever it is that you are counting on to clear you in the Day of Judgment, it’s not enough.
The gospel is from beginning to end something that God does, not something that we do.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Develop the 'gratitude' section more concretely: what does a life 'guided by the Spirit' look like in practice beyond just 'doing right things'?

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon excels here. It takes 'Judgment Day' and the 'two ways' (slavery vs. freedom, flesh vs. spirit) with extreme seriousness. It explicitly rejects the 'liberal' tendency to ignore being lost.
quotes: You may think you don’t believe in Judgment Day, but you do. Everybody does.
Behaving in the proper way never can and never will deliver us from judgment.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Maintain the tension of the 'two ways' without allowing the 'bound will' argument to inadvertently suggest that human choice doesn't matter at all.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is clearly the telos. The sermon defines the Gospel as God's action in Christ, distinct from human religion. It correctly identifies the 'faith of Christ' as the source of rectification.
quotes: He was, he is, and he will be the power and the agent of God’s salvation. He is himself our deliverance from the judgment.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Explicitly link the 'two natures' of Christ to the solution of the 'bound will' to satisfy Dekker's dogmatic requirement.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 1,550 words, the sermon lasts about 15 minutes. According to Dekker, this is insufficient for the 'breadth' required for true 'depth.' It feels more like a thematic address than a sustained biblical exposition.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the exegetical section. Slow down the movement through the text to allow the 'depth' of the specific passage to emerge over at least 20 minutes.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short of Dekker's formal definition by failing to focus on a specific pericope and failing to meet the minimum 20-minute duration. It functions as a thematic lecture on Galatians rather than a 'recreation' of a specific text. However, it is substantively strong in its psychological depth, its refusal of general truths, and its serious treatment of the 'two ways' and human misery.
strengths: Sharp psychological analysis of the 'bound will' which 'undoes the theft' by the psychologist.
Courageous insistence on the reality of Judgment and the possibility of being lost.
Clear distinction between 'religion' (human work) and 'Gospel' (God's work).
weaknesses: Lack of formal specificity; the 'text' is an entire book, which leads to a survey rather than a deep-dive.
Insufficient length to achieve the 'breadth' Dekker demands for theological depth.
Over-reliance on external contemporary hooks (NY Times) at the expense of immediate scriptural immersion.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is an effective theological speech, but it is not yet a 'sermon' in the strict Dekkerian sense. It lacks the formal discipline of pericope-based exposition and the required temporal breadth. It is a 5/10: substantively rich but formally deficient.
